course.subject: MGMT
course.name: Entrepreneurship and Innovation
course.description: This is an interactive course that introduces knowledge about the creation and management of new business ventures. Attention is also given to key issues in corporate entrepreneurship, social entrepreneurship, and family businesses.

reviews.author: Cat
reviews.title: (極度主觀, 慎入)Never choose SAM GARG!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
reviews.comment_content: I did not know what I learnt... so blow water lol
reviews.comment_teaching:
He was very chur as he always pushed for more meetings and asked us to think and think...I knew that was good, but ai....

He was not that nice as compared to professors in general
reviews.comment_grading:
I know we/I deserve this grade but this poor grade completely JUST hindered me from achieving my GPA goal lol (cry)

Since there were no mid terms and finals, everything depended on project. Sam apparently did not like our project so we suffered through and through. We were below one SD despit many efforts put in writing.

I got C+.
reviews.comment_workload:
We needed to come up with a business idea and even used crowdfunding platform to promot our idea, that was really eye opening but it was very chur. We spent a lot of time and effort but everything was in vain :( We made video as well

And then in financials of the business plan, Sam required reasonable estimate where numbers should always be supported by statistics. I was doing financials and it was really mentally exhaused...even worse than doing acct exercises

reviews.author: bkirs
reviews.title: Not Recommended
reviews.comment_content: The professor just copied everything from the textbook and put the headings as bullet points in his slides. There were a total of 11 chapters, covering business feasibility, business model, financing, marketing etc, to teach you how to set up your business. Just read the textbook and you will be fine.
reviews.comment_teaching: I wondered if the professor really knew what he was doing. Each lecture lasted 2 hours and 50 minutes although there was a 15-minute break after around 1 hour. He spent almost 2/3 of the entire lecture talking nonsense and inviting students to present their assignments which were actually summaries of what he taught last week (I doubted if there was any), interesting facts from the textbook etc. When he finally started teaching, he kept repeating the same points again and again, which were quite irrelevant to the slides. There were lots of exchange students and they were relatively willing to interact with the professor in class. He could not handle questions well and would say something confusing when he did not have the answer. However, he seemed to think his teaching was insightful as he loved asking students if they learnt something from the class. I could not understand why he was hired for UG / MBA programs.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading scheme was not transparent. The professor only published the grade and related statistics for Quiz 1 on Canvas. For the assignments, he provided letter grades only. Nobody knew how well they performed as no grades / statistics were offered regarding Quiz 2, attendance, participation, group project (presentation and business plan).

Attendance & Participation - 20%
Quiz 1 & Quiz 2 - 40%
Group Project (assignments) - 10%
Group Project (business plan & presentation) - 30%

I went to every class and got the highest score in Quiz 1 - that was the only thing I knew. The final letter grade was B+.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was crazy. There were weekly assignments for each group. When someone in your group did not contribute, it would be even more painful. The professor required students to finish reading a chapter every week and had high expectations for the group project. He would not tell you what he liked / disliked when you tried to generate a business idea. If you think there is much freedom, you are wrong. After my group submitted the business concept statement, he simply said our business would not work. We had to guess his preference and redo it again in addition to designing a new business model. At the end of the day, I did not think he liked our idea much as he kept questioning the profitability of the business. The final business plan had to be 30+ pages long covering various analysis that he only mentioned briefly in class. The textbook was the only thing we could rely on. It was really discouraging when he kept rejecting our ideas without providing guidance to improve the project.

reviews.author: abcde
reviews.title: FINAL WARNING: STAY AWAY FROM THIS TERRIBLE COURSE!
reviews.comment_content:
The content itself is very common sense and superficial. It fails to equip you with the essential skills to become a successful entrepreneur.

1.Innovative Ecosystems, Key Frameworks, and Class Networking
2. Creativity/Accelerating Ideas and Opportunities
3. Conducting Feasibility Analysis
4. Writing a Great Business Plan
5. Developing Your Business Model
6. Entrepreneurial Marketing
7. Venture Financing
8. Negotiations and Partnerships
reviews.comment_teaching:
He was the most unfriendly professor I have ever met in my entire university life. He always scold students for being late and failing to answer his questions. You are required to read about 10 pages of reading before each class; or you will be punished by him if you are caught. His teaching was boring and not inspiring at all.  

He always gave vague instructions and made students feel confused. For example, he once said that there would be no lecture in the following week. But, the truth is you still had to appear in class to to discuss the project with your teammates. He did not make it clear and many students were misled. Their attendance was negatively affected.

He also failed to make a clear guideline for the essay. He clarified it just a few hours before the deadline!
reviews.comment_grading:
FINAL GRADE: C range
TOTALLY RUINED MY CGA!! (since it is a 4 credit course)

I have spent so much time working on the group project, but I could not get any reward from him!!




Individual Component (45%)

Attendance and participation (20%)
Case Quizzes (5%)
Reflection essay (20%)

Team Component (55%)

Opportunity Analysis write-up + Elevator Pitch (10%)
Business Plan write-up (25%) + Presentation (10%)
Crowdfunding Campaign (10%)

If you want a good grade, please tailor made a product for him. He is exceptionally subjective. If he does not love your product, he will do whatever it takes to challenge you. He will ask for many statistics and figures, which are actually impossible to provide without doing a real and professional market research.
reviews.comment_workload:
Extremely heavy workload.
Don't be misled by the fact that this course has no exams.
You have to meet your group mates very often.

The course did not teach us a lot of technical skills. But, it requires us to produce a 100% real and justified business plan. You have to really think about the logistics, financing, accounting budget, marketing plan, HR of your proposed company. After writing the plan, i assure that you can really start doing business!
The most unacceptable part is the crowdfunding. It requires students to launch a crowdfunding campaign on a unpopular platform. AND, 10% of our grade depends on HOW MUCH MONEY WE HAVE RAISED! HOW RIDICULOUS IT IS! Many students were actually putting their own money to make their result looks nice!

reviews.author: Chanh2_
reviews.title: Good Grade Course + Light Workload + Nice Professor & TA
reviews.comment_content:
It is about 13 lectures.
Most of them are entrepreneur concepts e.g. what is angel fund, what is the possible challenge for social start up etc.
Some contents related to simple calculations
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Sayan and TA Barry are pretty nice.
Questions and responses are always welcomed during his lectures.
Sometimes he will ask follow-up questions after you answer the question. But if you cannot answer it, it is fine.
reviews.comment_grading:
Weekly Quiz x 9 (50%)
They are case study, students need to write 300 words for each quiz.
Participation + Attendance = 20%
The professor will mark down students who are late for lectures.
Group Project (30%)
1 Business Proposal + 1 Pre-recorded Presentation Video + 1 PowerPoint
My scores for your reference
Best 5 quiz = 45/50
Business Proposal = 9/10
Presentation + PowerPoint =?
At the end I got B+
reviews.comment_workload:
It is a 4 credit course with light workload.
The workload is similar to the 2 credit course MGMT 2130.

reviews.author: Gurlin
reviews.comment_content:
Interesting content, learned a lot about entrepreneurship

learned a lot about industry and technical
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teacher expects you to do too much
very hands on teaching, lots of group work and presenting and class discussion

guest speakers from industry
reviews.comment_grading:
participation marks
no exams
report writing

you lose marks for missing class!! Attendance is a must
reviews.comment_workload:
HEAVY
prof expects you to actually start a business
like he wants you to raise money with your group
you have to come up with an idea that is heavily critiqued by everyone and then role with it because you don't have time to do anything else

only worthwhile if you actually want to start your own company

reviews.author: Elizabeth
reviews.title: Lots of Work
reviews.comment_content: Content of this course is interesting, but perhaps a bit elementary. First class we discussed creativity, and he went around the room asking students "if they were creative or not." Sort of interesting discussion related to entrepreneurship but not super amazing.
reviews.comment_teaching: Great teacher who is approachable. However, is definitely strict and expects a ton from students. Favors students who put in lots of effort, participation, and effort. Is not fond of slackers or free-riders and can tell who is one of those people.
reviews.comment_grading: Harsh grader, again, expects a TON from students and expects them to really give every assignment 110%, and if not up to his standards, will dock points.
reviews.comment_workload: LOTS of group work, particularly outside the classroom. You have to work in a team of 4+ which is pretty difficult to coordinate most times with everyone's busy schedule.

reviews.author: hoihoi123
reviews.title: Extremely heavy workload and very demanding professor
reviews.comment_content:
Good:
Had lots of interesting guest speaker lecture.

Bad:
Completed a detailed Business Plan within a semester with LOTS OF ONGOING ASSESSMENTS that demanded frequent meetings (about once a week) with group mates outside classes.
reviews.comment_teaching: Sam required active participation in class. He always asked students to answer his questions even though they did not raise their hands. So you have to be well prepared for class by reading the case studies and required reading materials before EACH lesson.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was actually very subjective as it relied on whether Sam liked your group's idea. Also, he was demanding e.g. he required MANDATORY meetings with him and with crowdfunding mentors for many times. For the project, he asked many questions during the Q&A session and he required lots of statistical evidence to support the idea in the presentation.
reviews.comment_workload:
Think twice before you enroll this course because of unreasonably HEAVY workload!!! Assessments with * are the most demanding.
Attendance and participation (20%)
Case Quizzes (5%)
Reflection essay (20%)
Opportunity Analysis write-up + Elevator Pitch (10%) *
Business Plan write-up (25%) + Presentation (10%) *
Crowdfunding Campaign (10%) *

reviews.title: avoid this instrustor, not only this course
reviews.comment_content: blow water. this whole course emphasis entrepreneurship is about uncertainty.  it cannot be taught then what is the meaning of this course?
reviews.comment_teaching:
i dont want to do personal attack. but this instructor and TA are the worst people i met in ust. not only the teaching, but his 'mean' personality. if anyone wants to see your name typed on instructor's slide, try this course!

i guess most of people reg this course to fullfill the major requirement. u better wait for next sem if u dont want to suffer from his torment. just pay attention to the enrollment number during add/drop period. u will see a significant drop after the first class.
reviews.comment_grading: If u find that he doesnt like u, run. the grading is according to his personal liking. no matter how hard u work. so run.
reviews.comment_workload:
heavy, especially the reach-out report. he expected u to hold some real events, for god sake, he think everyone is free as him.

the workload is not only about the course, u need spend lots of time act as a bootlicker. of coz, as i said, if he doesnt like u, there is no point of working hard. becuase u will end up broken grade anyways.

reviews.author: Timmy178
reviews.comment_content: The course addresses the basic knowledge of entrepreneurship, relating to starting and managing a new business. The concepts are not difficult, and he would often invite quality guest speakers who'd make the classes seem more interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Sam is patient in answering questions, which could usefully help the grading of your presentations etc. He could be monotone at times but generally quite humorous.
reviews.comment_grading:
Individual Component Includes:

  In-class Participation (15%)
 Online Posts & Discussion (20%) 
Case Quizzes (20%)  

Team Component includes:
Initial Opportunity Analysis - presentation (10%)
 Final Opportunity Execution Plan - presentation and write-up (35%)

Grading is relatively strict, the professor tends to dig in with questions and require details.
reviews.comment_workload: Requires attention and effort in class. Students will need to often get together outside of class and work on scripts, reports and PPTs. There are many business cases to read, online simulations that take place on the weekends as well as discussions that require posting regularly could add stress to bus schedules.

reviews.author: Mixture
reviews.title: Course good for those who are interested in starting a business/joining a new venture
reviews.comment_content:
This course is mainly about the basic knowledge of entrepreneurship, with concepts related to creating and managing a new business. Those concepts are not difficult to understand, and through business cases study, guest speakers and online simulation, you will definitely have a better understanding on them.

Learning Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, you will be able to:

Understand and use key theoretical concepts in entrepreneurship and innovation from strategy and organisational perspective.

Come up with creative business ideas and evaluate their feasibility as entrepreneurial opportunities, and present these ideas effectively

Assess the interplay of startups, established corporations, and other key players in the ecosystem

Manage the tradeoffs involving cofounders, hires, investors, and board members in your startup
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Sam is patient to answer our questions about the group project even we have made several appointment for it. His respond helps quite a lot for the project progress. He is also quite humorous during the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Individual Component (55%):

In-class Participation (15%)
Online Posts & Discussion (20%)
Case Quizzes (20%)

Team Component (45%):

Initial Opportunity Analysis - presentation only (10%)
Final Opportunity Execution Plan - presentation and write-up (35%)

I manage to get above mean in most of the tasks, and able to get the highest score in the final opportunity execution plan (thanks for my great teammates).

Final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: From the grading you can see there are quite a lot of tasks to do in this course. You have to read 5 business cases, write 3 online posts and do project with 2-3 teammates. There are also 2 online simulations which are hold out of class time (often on Sat). SO if you decide to join, you are expected to spent quite a lot of time on the course. Yet, this is a 4 credit course and I think its fine in this case.

reviews.author: hltai
reviews.title: Heavy Workload Easy exam
reviews.comment_content:
The content is not very difficult. Easy to understand.

Entrepreneurship is an interesting and important subject which helps shape aspiring students en route to become managers, industry practitioners and business leaders in the modern economy. Students undertaking this course will be introduced to some of the basic elements of entrepreneurship manifested in issues, challenges and rewards of new venture creation. The process in creating a start-up company, indeed, the process of an entrepreneurial undertaking will be examined, discussed, and practised in class in order to provide students with some first-hand experience in the subject matter.
◼ Course objectives
The objectives of this course are for students:
1. To understand the processes, the importance and challenges of entrepreneurship from a societal and personal development viewpoints.
2. To understand the factors that may be influential in determining the outcomes of an entrepreneurial undertaking, typically, in the form of new venture creation.
3. To learn to develop an acumen for opportunities and risks identification for modern business.
4. To develop an understanding of the basic necessities of management, marketing and financial aspects of starting up a new business venture.
5. To learn how to develop a business plan for entrepreneurial venture.
6. To appreciate the cultural factors and the impacts of globalisation on entrepreneurial undertakings.
7. To develop the business acumen in conducting businesses in culturally diverse settings.
reviews.comment_teaching: He doesn't really teach. There is a presentation about the summary of the textbook chapter every lecture. But he gives very detailed comments and guidance on group projects.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is quite good. Just attend every lecture and do well in the group project.

1.
Individual Attendance
Attendance is taken in each class.
10/100

2.
Class Participation 10/100
Class participation is the critical part of the course. Participation is in the forms of class presentations, reviews of reading materials, course recaps and class discussion. Class participation marks may be earned by:
i. Group  5/100
ii. Individuals 5/100
Records will be kept throughout the courses.


3.
Quizzes (individual in-class assignments in the form of multiple choices) 40/100
iii. Mid-term Quiz (1 hour, 30 multiple choices questions) 20/100
iv. End of term Quiz (1 hour, 30 multiple choices questions) 20/100

4.
Group Project: Business plan development 40/100
i. Presentation of new business concept statement 5/100
ii. Presentation of the business model 5/100
iii. Presentation of the new business venture to investors 15/100
iv. Submission of business plan 15/100
reviews.comment_workload: Quite heavy workload as you have to do many readings before each lecture.

reviews.author: deetee
reviews.title: Highly recommend taking this course! (Lots of simulations, discussions and scope for creativity)
reviews.comment_content: The content is pretty rich. It covers a lot of areas including Innovative Ecosystems, Accelerating Ideas and Opportunities, Frameworks for understanding innovation, Responding to External Innovation, Feasibility Analysis of Ideas, Developing Your Business Model, Digital Platforms, Business Model Testing and Evolution, Venture Financing, Negotiations and Partnerships, Founding Team Dynamics, Board Relationships, Growth Issues and finally, Corporate Entrepreneurship. There are many guest lectures, and opportunities to meet entrepreneurs from across the world, as the prof has many connections. Great class for networking, too, actually! Highly recommended for those who are interested in entrepreneurship or building their leadership skills. Lots of in-class activities and simulations which will keep you engaged and busy and boost your critical thinking and creativity! The HBS simulation was honestly amazing, it taught me so so much :))
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Garg allows students to ask a lot of questions, and also asks them a lot of questions. While this may come off as rude to some, it really does help you grow and succeed in the long-run.
I know that all the reviews here are so negative, but I CAN ASSURE YOU that Prof Garg IS MUCH MUCH BETTER than what has been said here.
reviews.comment_grading: He rewards you for your participation and what ideas you bring to the table. A genuine effort is always rewarded in this class. Ended up with an A+ (my first one at UST yayy)
reviews.comment_workload: An average workload for a 4 credit course. Cmon guys it's a 4000 level course, and it can't get any better. You learn so much from all the activities and games, esp the simulations. Being *present* in class and putting in some amount of effort for your course work is honestly ALL you need to get a good grade here.

reviews.author: sssssss
reviews.comment_content: Contents are somewhat interesting and useful if you are interested in the field.  At least three lectures are entrepreneur experience sharing from three guests who have created different business
reviews.comment_teaching: Many in-class discussion and group discussion, the professor is nice and easygoing and willing to share his own opinion about your ideas. Many guests lectures and presentation on class.
reviews.comment_grading:
participation marks; report writing; in-class discussion and too much reply on your group project (55%); three to four reading quiz, never be late for the quiz, otherwise no marks and no make-up.

Attendance is a must, you lose marks for missing class!
Not a bad grade course but also not good grade, completely depend on your group project and groupmates
reviews.comment_workload: Heavy, non-stop group meeting and presentation and report

reviews.author: Um
reviews.comment_content: Basically is learning how to do a business plan.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is a nice person. He always say 'round of applause' in Chinese. However,  I do not know what  did I learn from his class lol
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Individual Attendance
Attendance is taken in each class. 10/100

2.  Class Participation
Class participation is the critical part of the course. Participation is in the forms of class presentations, reviews of reading materials, course recaps and class discussion. Class participation marks may be earned by:
i. Group5/100
ii. Individuals5/100
Records will be kept throughout the courses.
3.
Quizzes (individual in-class assignments in the form of multiple choices)
iii. Mid-term Quiz (1 hour, 30 multiple choices questions) 20/100
iv. End of term Quiz (1 hour, 30 multiple choices questions) 20/100

4.
Group Project: Business plan development
i. Presentation of new business concept statement 5/100
ii. Presentation of the business model  5/100
iii. Presentation of the new business venture to investors15/100
iv. Submission of business plan 15/100

Actually the grading mostly depends on the Group Project. If Professor likes your group and presentation, then you will get a good grade.  If not, it is just fair grade.
reviews.comment_workload: You have to come to write a business plan and present it to the angel investors by the end of semster

reviews.author: strawberry cake
reviews.comment_content: A course about starting your own business and writing business plans. not particularly interesting
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecture slides are pretty empty, it would be better if you just read the textbook. The professor often talked about this own experiences which is irrelevant to the course.
reviews.comment_grading: Slight above mean scores with high class participation got a B+
reviews.comment_workload: There are two quizzes and a project (presentation + report). The report is complete business plan that your group have to start from scratch and is aprrox 50 pages long. You are expected to read a chapter of the textbook every week and do a summary in groups which you may have to present it in class to earn group class participation marks.

reviews.author: nononope
reviews.title: Amazing Intro. course into Entrepreneurship
reviews.comment_content: I would disagree with all the older comments on this course - i think it was a great course with great teachers. This course is very thorough goes deep into all aspects of starting your business as well as into later stage start-ups. From idea generation to execution it covers everything, with this course you'll have the necessary knowledge to pursue innovation and entrepreneurship, i have saved my notes and will refer to them well into the future.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Sarkar and his TA ,Barry, were both amazing. They stayed till the end to answer everyone's questions and i really liked the discussion based class setting, the quality which should be for a 4000-course.

He knew what he was talking about, and you could tell he has experience and passion in this field, he wasn't just reading off the slides - he knew everything in depth and detail.
reviews.comment_grading:
Individual Component (60%)
- In-class Participation (20%)
- Online Posts & Discussion (20%)
- Case -based Assignments (20%)
Team Component (40%)
- Initial Opportunity Analysis – pitch (10%)
- Final Opportunity Execution Plan - pitch (30%)

i got a B+ in the end - messed up on some of the quizzes and missed a class or two.
reviews.comment_workload:
You really have to show up for every class, and be attentive to the discussions and contribute well - you cant half-ass it. If you can't contribute thoughtfully or intuitively, it will be hard to keep up.

The workload was minimal in terms of physical work, weekly readings ranging from 3-6 hours, occasionally there would be assignments where you have to write 30-50 words for an online class discussion forum (can't half-ass this discussion), and also 4 quizzes which really were 200 words on a certain case study and your opinions on it. The final group pitch and mid term group  pitch was demanding tho, a lot of effort needs to be done.

Again, not a lot for a 4 credit course.

reviews.author: UST1234
reviews.comment_content: TBH the content wasn't hard, the concepts and theories were easy to get, more like common sense to me
reviews.comment_teaching:
I think it was soso, he spent so much time blowing water, and sitting there for 3 hours is quite hard. He would take a break for 15 mins after one hour so it makes life easier.
We would need the textbook for the course, he made us read each chapter before each class then to pick a group to present some of the 'interesting findings' in front of the class. That was okay just mention some keypoints would do. Towards the end of the semester, I noticed he started to ask for the names of those presented and that may contribute to the attendance.
Normally he would go through the whole powerpoint deck, but sometimes he just blew too much water and forgot about the slides.

The professor himself was okay, even though he called out students' name a lot, it's also okay if you couldn't answer his question.

ps. many exchange students attended this course (probably because many of them are seriously considering a startup)
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Individual Attendance 10%
2. Class Participation 10%
3. Quizzes 40%
4. Group Project 40%

my grades:
attendance ??
class participation ??
quiz 1: 27/30 quiz 2: 26/30
group project ???

basically I only know the grades for the quizzes, the prof only gave letter grades for the first few tasks related to the final business plan and I heard almost every group got the same grade, so seriously got no idea how he graded.

I think he values the project a lot, your business idea has to be really feasible and better that it's in progress already. He invited 3 of his friends to come listen our presentation, making it a real pitching for angel investors. I guess our idea was really feasible that's why our team got a really high grading.

My final grade was A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
quite a lot of workload.

As mentioned, 'interesting findings' every lesson, plus the reading before each class. He also gave 4 pieces of additional reading towards the end of the semester and those were hell thick.

You would also be working on the business idea during the early semester, then handing in assignments once in 2 weeks.

reviews.author: W76
reviews.title: Interesting class, experience how to write a business plan and pitch
reviews.comment_content:
The classes were mainly structured by:
1. Lectures
2. Case readings
3. Speakers sharing
4. Project time

It was practical - the cases and sharings reinforced what we had learnt durin lectures by actual examples (both successful and failed ones).

I learnt a lot through writing a business plan, and doing the pitch deck. I also learnt a lot as a team leader (aka CEO of the business idea), as a local student, I worked with non-local teammates and exchange students, it was challenging for me to coordinate and understand cultural differences. This experience helped me to experience the pains being an entrepreneur (which is my goal). I am extremely grateful to have such experience.

After the course, I even pitched my ideas to some investors who showed interests.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Sam was a nice professor (though a lot of people think he's not friendly). He's demanding and he does scold people sometimes, but I could tell that he put a lot if efforts in this class (at least that's what I felt). He needed to spend a lot of tell to look at our assignments and prepare for the class as well.

After the final pitch, he told me that the idea was good, and I could let him know if I need anything to bring the idea further, and he was happy to help.
reviews.comment_grading:
I got an A in this class, though our group did poorly in the entrepreneur interview write up. He definitely rewarded efforts, as he knew I was the group leader, I scored higher than the other group mates.

One of my groupmates (an exchange student) cheated in the quiz (the quiz was 1% of the overall grade), and he knew that, he turned out to get a C in this class. So obviously the grades aren't too bad.
reviews.comment_workload: I have to be honest that the workload was really high. Readings and assignments almost every week. Had to communicate and meet with your teammates very often in order to get thigs done because it involves lots of group work. But overall it was pleasant and I enjoyed it.

reviews.author: joyceleung0913
reviews.title: MGMT 4220
reviews.comment_content: The content is all about your creativity, if you can think of a  good idea, and you are a good pitcher, it's a pretty nice course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is alright I think. Not too bad not too good.
reviews.comment_grading: Some people said his grading is harsh but I think he looks a lot into effort. If you can show him the effort your group put in, you will be fine.
reviews.comment_workload: He warned us about the workload so i think everyone who take this course is prepared for the heavy workload. Reading every lesson and many preparations to do. He will cold call on students to answer his questions so you can hide.

reviews.author: booboo
reviews.comment_content: The course mainly focus on entrepreneurship and innovation in business, the whole lecture time is mainly focusing on the content from the textbook and some day to day example from professor, the content is somehow boring.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor teaching style is really boring and wordy, he keeps repeating the facts and information from the textbook which the students can read the book themselves instead of mentioning over and over again during the precious lecture time. He also invite students to recap his teaching and textbook every lecture, which it is considered as wastage of time.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is pretty good, i think the grading really depends on the performance of the group project, if you can catch his attention of your project idea at first and keep it up, it's easy to obtain at least B+ from him.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is crazy and heavy, it requires every group to write a formal business plan of 30 pages, as well as a 15 minutes presentation for the project.

reviews.author: mz
reviews.comment_content: All the things are from textbook. Read the textbook. From business model, marketing to funding. A snapshot of all the business topics. There is nothing difficult for this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Not that good. He was very lack of insights on entrepreneurship. The course itself is good but the instructor is to some extent very bad.
reviews.comment_grading:
It's ok.

Attendance, participation, assignments and a final business plan (with a business presentation). The presentation is to a VC guy and a banker.
reviews.comment_workload:
Normal
Have some weekly assignments, 2 quizs, one presentation and one 35-page business plan. It really depends on your teammates.

reviews.author: Anitha
reviews.title: Would recommend if you are genuinely interested in startups!
reviews.comment_content: The content is not too hard! Most of it is interesting as I was able to learn new concepts about startups. I personally would recommend to buy or borrow the assigned textbook as it is very helpful. I have attached the syllabus below for further information.
reviews.comment_teaching: He is one my favourite professors at UST. He makes the 3 hour class super interesting and engaging with his personal business opportunities and experiences. He also has a habit of repeating himself multiple times during the lecture so you may not have to read the textbook to remember certain concepts.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading was great!

Individual Attendance = Attended all classes as they were very interesting

Class Participation = Actively participated during lectures

Quizzes = Both quizzes were above mean (mean = around 25/30)

Final presentation = the score was not released but according to professor's feedback he was very impressed with our presentation

Final Grade = A
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is not too heavy as the quizzes are based on individual performances. However, things were chaotic during the preparation of final presentation as we had to deal with 2 free riders.

reviews.author: ustbuddy
reviews.title: good grade if you have good groupmates
reviews.comment_content:
mainly teach and entrepreneurship topics
whole course consist of lectures and projects.
For example, he taught how to form a team for startup at the beginning of semester. Then slowly progress to idea simulation and how to sustain startup.
reviews.comment_teaching: professor Sam is very knowledgeable about startups and he invited many guest speakers who share some interesting ideas to us
reviews.comment_grading:
there is no midterms or final. the grade depends on your participation and the projects. So it is crucial to find a good team, better reg with your friends.
You have to write a reflective essay at the end.
reviews.comment_workload: depends on your group mates and you have to read the require reading before every lecture. the professor will ask some questions. There will be a few quizs on cases.
